Improvement of energy utilization efficiency in Malaysian buildings especially in the commercial and government sectors by promoting energy conserving design of new buildings and improving energy utilization in existing buildings.

Biodiversity Conservation in multiple-use forest landscape in Sabah, Malaysia
Biodiversity conservation in multiple-use forest landscapes in Sabah, Malaysia.
first-order administrative division
independent political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

To institutionalize a multipleuse forest landscape planning and management model which brings the management of critical protected areas and connecting landscapes under a common management umbrella implementation of which is sustainably funded by revenues generated within the area
Conservation of globally and nationally significant biodiversity within project landscape

comment.narrative:
Biodiversity is being depleted at project landscape level due to habitat loss degradation and fragmentation
Project landscape currently contains no Class I Protected Forest
Wildlife populations within the project landscape together with those at adjacent protected areas are currently estimated at
A Elephants 0510 Indkm2
B Organg utan 0510 Indkm2
C Sun Bear lt10 or gt30 Indkm2
D Clouded Leopard lt10 or gt30 Indkm2
However the baseline and target indicators for wildlife populations are subject to revision based on findings of data gathering and synthesis work to be launched in early 2015 This review will also advise on whether and how including baseline and target populations to include Banteng Tembadau as an indicator species
Natural capital being lost through habitat conversion and degradation
Different types of forests in the project landscape
a Primary forest 18517 ha Note Primary forest area subject to revision based on findings of data gathering and synthesis subcontract and incorporated thereafter into the NNL baseline analysis
b Secondary forests 242747 ha

Genetic species and ecosystem diversity conserved in approximately 261000 ha of the KalabakanGunung Rara area within a sustainablymanaged forest landscape of 393544 ha including adjacent protected areas
By end of project at least 500000 ha of project landscape established as new Class I Protected Forest
Updated target 145000 ha
A Elephants 1015 Indkm2
B Organg utan 2035 Indkm2
C Sun Bear gt20 Indkm2
D Clouded Leopard gt20 Indkm2
No net loss in levels of biodiversity and other ecosystem functions ie full maintenance of natural capital within project landscape over project period with plan in place for continued maintenance
No decrease in primary forest areas
A 30 increase annual increase in the budget allocation for Class I Protected Forest Reserves
Amended to
Genetic species and ecosystem diversity conserved in approximately 261000 ha of the KalabakanGunung Rara Forest Reserves within a sustainablymanaged forest landscape of 393544 ha including adjacent protected areas
By the end of the project at least 145000 ha of project landscape established and effectively managed as new Class I Protected Forest
A Elephants 1015 Indkm2
B Organg utan 2035 Indkm2
C Sun Bear gt20 Indkm2
D Clouded Leopard gt20 Indkm2
The project seeks as an overarching target to avoid and minimise impacts on biodiversity including through plantation development and plans to achieve NNL of biodiversity within the Project area While onsite mitigation is a strong preference if this proves unattainable NNL of biodiversity should be achieved through offsite compensation eg via the conservation of forests neighboring the Project site
No decrease in primary forest areas

As reported last year a land mark decision was made to gazett 95486 ha of former natural forest management areas within the project landscape as a Class I Protection Forest Reserve This has increased the Class 1 reserve and conservation areas within the project area from 18517 ha to 115673 ha and has exceeded the original projects target of 50000 ha linking three important conservation areas Maliau Basin Danum Valley and Imbak Canyon Nevertheless in the Inception Report a new project target has been set at least 145000 ha by the end of the project However as of 30th June 2015 the total area of Class I Forest Reserves in the project area has increased to 30627 ha while the total area under Class VI Virgin Jungle Reserve VJR is 4655 ha All these forest reserves were gazetted on 24th December 2014 This means that the total Protected Areas PA in the project area as of 30th June 2015 is 150955 ha This has already exceeded the new project target of 145000 ha
The commitment of the SFD to pursue the NoNetLoss NNL policy in the State of Sabah and in the project landscape has been reiterated and strengthened Forest Trends a consultant group based in USA has been appointed by the SFD in December 2014 to undertake a Policy and regulations Assessment for Implementing NNLNG of Biodiversity in Sabah The final report which is expected to be finalized in December 2015 will highlight amongst others the recommendations to inform the drafting of a New Forest Policy andor changes in existing policies and institutional structures needed to implement these changes that focus on
Implementing NNLNG of biodiversity
Incorporating biodiversity conservation and ecological functionality into landscape level planning and management for multiple landuses
Management tools needed for effective implementation eg management agreements conservation trust funds etc with the principal elements of implementation guidelines
The role of key stakeholders and
The government commitments required for this package of measures to work
Besides the SFD commitment on NNL policy biodiversity assessments are planned which will be able to gauge the progress with regard to the species population estimates In this case a subcontract on Landscape level biodiversity and forest quality assessment and mapping using Lidar and Hyperspectral Imagery will be awarded to Carnegie Institution for Science USA while another subcontract on Ground based biodiversity assessments using a range of key taxa mapping monitoring programmes will be awarded to a small consortium of leading scientists

The Sabah Forestry Department and Yayasan Sabah have enhanced capacities and experience with the model needed to enable its maintenance and replication

A Enabling environment 83 87

The midterm capacity score assessment will be conducted in the next reporting period In January 2015 the SFD contracted Forest Trends to conduct on Policy and Regulations Assessment for Implementing No Net LossNet gain of Biodiversity in Sustainable Multipleuse Forest landscape in Sabah Results of this will lay a foundation for improved and biodiversity friendly multiple use forest management systems and provide an enabling policy and regulatory environment ready to facilitate expansion replication of the model i to other forest landscapes in Sabah that include or will include protected forest reserves and ii to other PA subsystems in Sabah

description.narrative: Improved law enforcement effectiveness

comment.narrative: Law enforcement in the landscape is done by SFD and YS staff by means of mobile inspection and checkpoint at point of entry to the landscape There are 60 law enforcement staff and patrolling is conducted on a daily basis Of these 60 half have been awarded honorary wildlife warden status with powers of arrest In 2010 there were less than five cases of fines

Increase in the ratio of number of fines collected relative to law enforcement efforts
Note To be reviewed once information acquired
The next assessment is due prior to the midterm review in 2016

description.narrative: State and national guidelines and operational policies for multipleuse forest landscape planning management and conservation

comment.narrative: Sustainable Forest Management License Agreement SFMLA
By end of Y3 policy and guidelines specific to multipleuse forest landscape established

This indicator would have to rely or has corresponding outputs from SC6a Landscape level biodiversity and forest quality assessment and mapping using LiDAR and hyperspectral imagery and SC6b Groundbased biodiversity assessment using a range of key taxa mapping and monitoring programs of which these services will be carried out in 2016 This indicator also depends on the outcomes of the three consultancy services that is i SC2 Development of Statelevel policy options and mechanisms for PES ii SC3 Development of international policy options and mechanisms for PES and iii Policy and regulations assessment for implementing NNLNG of biodiversity in sustainable multipleuse forest landscape Sabah SC1 All these consultancies are expected to commence during the last quarter of 2015

description.narrative: Statelevel policies and regulations for generating revenues from innovative financing mechanisms and reinvesting into PA and sustainable multipleuse forest landscape planning and management

comment.narrative: No policies or regulations
By end of Y5 new statelevel policies and regulations in place for generating and reinvesting revenues from innovative financing mechanisms

Calling for consultancy service on this indicatorissue was made in May and again in July whereby a consultant Green Spider has been successfully appointedThe duration of the consultancy is four 4 years commencing in September 2015

description.narrative: Statelevel system for ensuring no net loss NNL of biodiversity from existing forest landscapes

comment.narrative: NNL is a new concept for Sabah

By end of Y2 statelevel policies and regulations supporting NNL finalized
Statelevel NNL system in place by end of year 6 Y6
Amended to
Pilot implementation of NNL component 2 within project landscape provides initial practical lessons for drafting statelevel policy
State level policy and regulation on NNL drafted in Y2
Statelevel NNL regulation in place by end of year 5 Y5

The commitment to No Net Loss NNL within the project landscape has been reiterated and strengthened So besides actions taken as reported in 2014 the SFD has appointed Forest Trends to formulate a new forest policy in support of Output 11 of Component 1 of the project that is new Statelevel policies and regulations for implementing no net loss NNLnet gain NG of biodiversity
So far two reports have been produced and were presented by Forest Trends in the workshops The second workshop which was held on 16th June 2015 Forest Trends presented the required policy changes and implementation structure for Sabah with regards to NNLNG of biodiversity The workshop recommended that the Sabah Forestry Department should undertake the landuse pilot project the scoping study and net gain costbenefit study In addition there was a proposal that the Government of Sabah should draft guidelines and a roadmap of the steps that would be needed to develop and put in place a regulatory NNLNG system These proposed supplementary studies and recommendations will be deliberated in the next Project Board meeting In the meantime Forest Trends will come up with the policy recommendations and guidelines on NNLNG of biodiversity by December 2015

description.narrative: Systems for compliance monitoring and enforcement of multiple use forest regulations

comment.narrative: Generic ME guidelines no training materials

By end of project a revised and updated set of regulations and guidelines for compliance monitoring and enforcement within a multiple use context that includes innovative revenue generating instruments

In Progress A subcontract on Ground Based Biodiversity Assessments using a range of key taxa Mapping Monitoring Programmes SC6b has been given to Carnegie Institution for Science USA to further study on this issue The duration of this contract is 4 years
In addition a consultancy on Development of statelevel policy options and mechanisms for payment for ecosystem services SC 2 was advertised in early May 2015 This consultancy services require the consultant to
i Support the development of new Statelevel policies and regulations options and mechanismsguidelines that regulate and govern biodiversity conservation and the application of financial mechanisms relating to Payment for Ecosystem Services PES in Sabah and
ii Develop a workable institutional framework to support a PES scheme in Sabah

The consultancy services that are relevant to the issuestarget level are

description.narrative: Habitat conserved and degradation reduced under landscape level management plan

comment.narrative: Forest plantation occupies 15 of total project landscape baseline scenario to be determined as part of model development

Land use for agricultural production at least 60 lower compared with baseline scenario
Amended to At a minimum a large majority of the biodiversity losses expected under current scenario 2 will be avoided mitigated andor offset within the landscapes

Based on the signed MoU between the SFD and UNDP the landuse allocation for ITP or Agroforestry in the project area is 9937 ha and for agriculture the total gross area is 3783530 ha that is oilpalm plantations 35878 ha and organic agriculture 19573 ha This means that the total gross area for forest plantation and agriculture in the project area was reduced from 54967 ha to 477723 ha The area will be further reduced assuming that only 70 of the gross area can be converted to oilpalm plantations which means that a large majority of the biodiversity losses will be avoided mitigated andor offset within the landscape

comment.narrative: No plan implementation

New PA established ecological corridors watershed salt lick
Sustainableuse management system based on sustainable offtake no net loss monitoring and enforcement

Sustainableuse management system based on sustainable offtake no net loss monitoring and enforcementespecially of hunting

As mentioned earlier a large Class I Protection Forest Reserves and VJR have been gazetted within the project area
The new Class I Protection Forest Reserves that have been gazetted on 24th December 2014 are as follows
i Gunung Rara Wildlife Corridor FR 10364 ha Wildlife Corridor
ii Maliau Buffer Zone FR Ext 5181 ha Ecological and Wildlife Corridor
iii Sg Anjeranjermut FR 3857 ha Ecological and Wildlife Corridor
iv Sg Sumagas FR 4215 ha Salt Lick and Wildlife Corridor
v Sg Tiagau FR Ext 7010ha Wildlife Corridor and Water Catchment
The new VJR that has been gazetted on 24th December 2014 is Sg Imbak FR Ext 4655 ha Ecological
The Project will support management planning for these areas and other areas of different land uses

Adaptive system in place by Y2
Transparent mechanism that allows stakeholders to track revenue generated from proposed multipleuse activities in project site and the amount of each that is channeled back for conservation

A Financial Data Management Specialist consultancy service was advertised in May and July 2015 A consultant Global Forestry Services GFS was the successful tenderer The consultancy period will be 16 working weeks within 12 months commencing in October 2015

description.narrative: Management budgets as of optimal management costs

comment.narrative: RM114 million 2010 budget represents approximately 57 of optimal management costs latter to be updated based on revised estimate of optimal management costs

description.narrative: Use of innovative revenue mechanisms for revenuegenerating conservation

comment.narrative: Only revenue generation is from timber concessions other ecosystem services remain unmonetized leading to overharvesting andor inappropriate timber harvesting methods

By end of Y2 optimal landuse matrix based on environmental economic considerations within project landscape are determined
By end of project three revenue generating mechanisms including REDD carbon biodiversity offsets and PES have been designed and piloted with total annual revenues projected to reach at least 50 of optimal management costs within five years following project completion

An international consultancy to look for an Environmental Economist IC 3 has been advertised in May 2015 The Environmental Economist is required amongst others to assess the total economic value of alternative landuse scenarios and ecosystems services The Technical Evaluation Committee TEC had convened their meeting on 29th June 2015 of which their recommendations will be deliberated by the Project Board in their meeting which is yet to be scheduled

independent political entity
Enhancing Effectiveness and Financial Sustainability of Protected Area in Malaysia
Enhancing Effectiveness and Financial Sustainability of Protected Area in Malaysia (PA)
first-order administrative division
first-order administrative division
region
Environment - policy, planning and administration

1. Increase in the Government of Malaysia's investment in PA management operation. 2. Financial sustainability scorecard for the 3 PA networks, which are DWNP, JNPC and PSPC. 3. Capacity development scorecard for the 3 PA networks, which are DWNP, JNPC and PSPC. 4. METT score for Taman Negara, Endau-Rompin and Royal Belum State Park

comment.narrative: 1a. USD 7.25 million in 2010 operating budget for the three protected area agencies, which are Department of Wildlife and National Parks (DWNP), Johor National Park Corporation (JNPC) and Perak State Park Corporation (PSPC). 1b. USD 6 million for three protected area networks namely, DWNP, JNPC and PSPC in 2011-2012 development budget under the 10th Malaysia Plan. 2. Financial sustainability scores for the 3 PA networks in 2010: DWNP (49.8%), JNPC (44.4%) and PSPC (40.0%). 3. Capacity development indicator score for the 3 PA networks in 2010: : DWNP (61%), JNPC (61%) and PSPC (45%). 4. Management Effectiveness Tracking Tool (METT) score in 2010: Taman Negara National Park (74), Endau-Rompin National Park (58) and Royal Belum State Park (53).

1.1 National framework for PA system with uniform criteria for PA establishment and management standards is endorsed by December 2015. 1.2 Resource mobilization strategy for ensuring long term financial sustainability of the National Natural Resource Conservation Fund is completed by December 2015. 2.1 Effective Protected Area and Wildlife Management certificate training course modules for mid-level protected area personnel is developed and launched by December 2015. 3.1 Initial draft of management and business plans for Taman Negara, Royal Belum and Endau-Rompin are produced by end of December 2015. 4.1 Midterm review is completed by December 2015.

1.1 Programme of Work on Protected Area containing guidelines for the National framework for PA system was drafted in September 2015. 1.2 The National Natural Resource Conservation Fund was launched in November 2015. Resource mobilization strategy for ensuring long term financial sustainability of the National Natural Resource Conservation Fund is postponed to 2016. 2.1 Effective Protected Area and Wildlife Management certificate training course modules for mid-level protected area personnel was developed and launched in November 2015, ahead of scheduled. 3.1 Initial draft of management and business plans for Taman Negara, Royal Belum and Endau-Rompin were produced by end of December 2015. 4.1 Midterm review is postponed to April - June 2016.

1.1 National framework for PA system with uniform criteria for PA establishment and management standards is developed by 31 December 2016. 1.2 Preliminary performance measurement indices for PA project selection under the 11th Malaysia Plan is proposed to NRE/EPU by December 2016. 1.3 Template for PA profile is developed and data collected by October 206. 1.4 Resource mobilization strategy for ensuring long term financial sustainability of the National Natural Resource Conservation Fund (NCTF) is completed by December 2016. 1.5 Final draft report for TEEB for PA is completed by 31 December 2016. 2.1 Financing strategy/plan is developed for DWNP and Johor National Park Corporation by December 2016. 2.2 Financing diversification strategy is developed for DWNP and Johor National Park Corporation by December 2016. 2.3 Capacity building programme is developed for the personnel of the Institute of Biodiversity by September 2016. 3.1 Draft PA management and business plan for Royal Belum is complete by 31 December 2016. 3.2 PA management plan for Taman Negara and Endau-Rompin are finalized and adopted by 31 December 2016. 3.3 PA business plan for Royal Belum, Taman Negara and Endau-Rompin are finalized and adopted by 31 December 2016. 4.1 Project is rated Satisfactory for Development Objective and Implementation Progress under the Project Implementation Review 2016 by UNDP-GEF. 4.2 Mid-term review report is completed by 31 October 2016.

description.narrative: To establish a performancebased financing structure to support effective Protected Area PA system management in Peninsular Malaysia

Financial sustainability scorecard for the 3 PA networks
DWNP
JNPC
PSPC

comment.narrative:
DWNP 558
JNPC 447
PSPC 531
Financial sustainability scorecards were completed in consultation with the three PA agencies and other key subnational authorities in March and May 2015 Preliminary results were collated and shared with the agencies highlighting the need for supplementary data Follow up meetings were held with each of the agencies to confirm and verify the final scores
The financial sustainability scores for DWNP JNPC and PSPC have recorded an increase with PSPC exceeded the target level at end of project 50 Part I of the financial sustainability scorecard reflects a gradual increase in budget allocation of the three PA networks In 2014 all the PA networks benefitted from substantial increase in development budget allocation mainly for the development of infrastructure beneficial to PA management such as roads Endau Rompin a jetty Royal Belum and other upkeep and maintenance works DWNP As these are oneoff allocation the figures can only be matched with PA networks continue to advocate for additional development budget through submission and approval of PA related project proposals that are in line with the development priorities of the 11th Malaysia Plan
In terms of revenue generated from the PAs Taman Negara National Park had a strong year buoyed by recognition of the 75th Anniversary of the Parks establishment However a devastating flood in the last quarter of 2014 in the park closure resulted in low visitor numbers from November 2014 to March 2015 Royal Belum State Park has demonstrated increased capacity to generate more revenue from visitors Despide of the serious flooding experienced in December 2014 the Parks collection from entrance fees and recreational related charges was more than double the 2010 baseline It has recorded steady visitor arrivals from Europe due to successful promotion in these highvalue niche markets thereby increasing revenue from tourism while upholding strong emphasis on conservation PSPCs higher score can be attributed to significant improvements in Part II which is a measure of capacity development for financial management and planning This is a result of better understanding of the financial planning and management system in place which includes technical support from the Perak State Government Adjustments were made to the Total Possible Score as several provisions were technically not applicable this includes some of the revenue diversification mechanisms which are currently not available and feasible As the financial score for PSPC exceeds the end of project target level it is recommended that a new target be set to provide scope for further improvement and benchmarking
Overall both JNPC and DWNP showed stronger financial sustainability scores edging closer to the end of project target level These stronger scores are also mainly attributed to improved scores in Part IIIn demonstrating improved capacity in planning and financial management DWNP for example has improved its financial data management to more accurately represent actual expenditure of PA management across the different states which was previously bundled with wildlife management costs
All three PA agencies have much room for improvement in terms of enhancing their scores in Part III which deals with tools for revenue generation by PAs Of the three JNPC has made some progress towards diversifying its sources of revenue a new Private Public Partnership PPP initiative at Pulau Kukup involving Iskandar Regional Development Authority and JNPC is currently being developed If successful this could present a new source of revenue for the JNPCs PA network

description.narrative: Increase in the Federal Government investment in PA management

comment.narrative:
USD 725 million in 2010 for the DWNP JNPC and PSPC
USD 6 million in 20112012 development budget under 10th Malaysia Plan

25 increase of operational budget in real terms for the 3 target PA networks based on aggregate funding from Federal and State Government source
25 increase in development budget under the 5year Malaysia Plan

Operating Budget The total operating budget for the three PA networks for 2014 was US1087 million MYR350 million a 50 increase compared to the 2010 baseline at US725 million The breakdown of operating budget of each PA network as follows
Department of Wildlife and National Park DWNP US769 million MYR2460 million
Johor National Park Corporation JNPC US250 million MYR80 million
Perak State Park Corporation PSPC US056 million MYR18 million
Development Budget In 2014 the total development budget allocated was US17 million MYR545 million a 183 increase from baseline level of US6 million The surge is mainly due to the implementation of infrastructure development projects such as wildlife crossing bridgeunderpass wildlife conservation centres and jetty habitat enrichment wildlife survey and inventory and wildlife conservation which have been earmarked since year 2011 and 2013 the first and second rolling plan of the 10th Malaysia Plan The breakdown of development budget of each PA network as follows
DWNP US5 million MYR16 million
JNPC US69 million MYR22 million
PSPC US51 million MYR165 million
Year 2014 exchange rate at US100 MYR320 is used to make comparable budget trends instead of current exchange rate which has seen Ringgit Malaysia depreciated significantly against US Dollar
This positive trend reflected an increased government commitment in protected area under the business as usual scenario as the performancebased financing structure for protected area is yet to be established piloted and institutionalized within the existing public finance and budgetary system

description.narrative: Effective sitelevel PA management
Improved management effectiveness as per METT scores for three target PAs

comment.narrative:
METT scores in 2010
Taman Negara 74
EndauRompin 58
Royal Belum 53

Average 10 increase in METT scores for 3 target PAs
TN 82
ER NP 68
RB 65

METT scores for 2014
Taman Negara NP 745 score 76
EndauRompin NP 598 score 61
Royal Belum SP 667 score 70
The METT score for Taman Negara remained little changed at 745 Generally while the park scored well in terms of professional experience and capacity and having good systems and structure it registered weaker scores associated with having adequate trained staff equipment technology and resources needed for effective management Many tools and assets need to be upgraded to support park management needs This is also in light of the increased threats associated with poaching activity within the park as well as higher risk of encroachment as land use change in converting the landscape surrounding the park from forest to plantations roads and other uses
The METT score for Endau Rompin registered a slight increase The increase reflects some positive developments for capacity building for park staff as well as strengthening research and monitoring via the MoA signed with Universiti Tun Hussein Onn The Strategic Plan Pelan Perancangan Strategik for 20122016 was reviewed in 2014 to and has been useful to strengthen Park management However the Park is hampered by the lack of a detailed Management and Business Plan and park staff are hampered in their ability to implement effective management due to resource and budget constraints The increased exposure of park boundaries roads and waterways to poachers is also an issue requiring urgent attention
Royal Belum SP recorded a higher score of 70 exceeding the project target This mainly reflects the strong institutional support from the state government for setting aside the State Park primarily as a PA for conservation The state and PSPC have put in place the necessary legal and management processes for planning management and reporting and planning however effective management continues to be hampered by lack of human resources for various aspects including enforcement research and monitoring and community engagement

description.narrative: Increase in gross revenue amount and revenue sources of the three demonstration PAs

comment.narrative:
Taman Negara MYR 350000 from entrance fees and recreational related charges
EndauRompin National Park MYR 999892 from entrance fees tourism and recreational charges income from concessions
Royal Belum State Park MYR 126000 from entrance fees and recreational related charges
20 increase in gross revenue for the 3 target PA sites over the project period

Taman Negara National Park MYR581585 from entrance fees and recreational related charges MYR152577 is revenue from resort concessionaire at Kuala Tahan
EndauRompin National Park MYR820955 from entrance fees tourism and recreational charges income from concessions
Royal Belum State Park MYR310000 from entrance fees and recreational related charges
Taman Negara National Park increased its collection in conjunction with the 75th Anniversary of the establishment of the Park However these gains were undercut by the impact of serious flooding which occurred in December 2014 The Project also produced a commemorative video and participated in an exhibition to help rekindle public interest in the Park
Both Endau Rompin National Park and Royal Belum State Park were affected by the December floods which continues to affect visitors in 2015 Despite this Royal Belum still managed to generate more than double its 2014 collection compared to the baseline It has also recorded steady visitor arrivals from European visitors due to promotion strategies abroad Endau Rompin NP recorded fewer visitor arrivals compared to the baseline The park recently doubled its visitor fees for nonMalaysians however the impact of this is not evident as currently Malaysians form the majority of the visitors to this park
Taman Negara has plan to introduce a new fee structure This is currently under the consideration of State Government of Pahang but the quantum and timeline for new structure is yet to be finalized A revised fee structure was introduced at EndauRompin in 2013 which has a two tier fee rates for locals and foreigners There are no plans yet for Royal Belum

description.narrative:
Length of park patrolled per year
Number of patrolling programmes per year
Percentage of the area patrolled per year
Number of patrolling staff
Number of illegal activity including encroachment and poaching cases within PA reported

comment.narrative:
Taman Negara 5 10 km per day
Taman Negara 8 10 days per month by walking
Taman Negara 10
Taman Negara 2 cases in 2010

25 increase
50 increase
25 increase
50 increase

In 2014 in addition to its regular patrols in Taman Negara DWNP carried out 6 joint patrols with Malaysian Armed Forces under the 1MBEON 1Malaysia Biodiversity Enforcement Operation Network Programme spearheaded by the governments National Blue Ocean Strategy NBOS NBOS is a federal government approach to formulate highimpact lowcost national strategies that are able to be rapidly executed often combining and reallocating existing resources and capacitiesThe funds received by DWNP for this programme in 2014 was MYR570000
A total of 636 personnel were involved in these patrols comprising 252 staff and 384 Army personnel
Area covered in Taman Negara NP 143300 Ha or 33 of the total park area
A total of 19 poachers were arrested and charged Encroachment activities in the boundary of the Park were uncovered and halted
The 1MBEON programme will continue in 2015 and will include Endau Rompin NP 3 joint patrols and Royal Belum NP 3 joint patrols There will again be six programmes in Taman Negara NP focussing on hotspot areas

description.narrative: Number of PAs successfully meeting national management criteria and accessing performancebased financial transfers from the Federal system

comment.narrative: No baseline exists

All 3 target PA sites have approved management and business financing plans
20 increase in federal allocation of funding

The development of management and business plan for the three sites commenced since January 2015 Two deliverables have been submitted namely the gap analysis and stocktaking report Standard template is being developed to describe key elements of a PA management and business plan and will be strengthened through stakeholder consultations
Federal allocation for the sites in year 2014 are
Taman Negara MYR 126 million US 394 million
EndauRompin MYR 220 million US 688 million
Royal Belum MYR 165 million US 516 million
Year 2014 exchange rate at US100 MYR320 is used

description.narrative: Tiger population as a flagship species in target PAs namely Taman Negara EndauRompin National Park and Royal Belum State Park

comment.narrative:
Estimated tiger population for year 2013
Taman Negara 18
EndauRompin National Park XX
Royal Belum State Park XX
Estimated tiger population for the three target PAs for year 2013 will be used as baseline and the baseline figures will be indicated in the next Project Implementation Review 2013 2014
50 increase in tiger population

The official figure made public in 2014 is 250 340 This is based on fieldbased data gathered from seven known tiger ranging areas in Peninsula Malaysia Estimates are based on camera trap surveys and field observation mainly by Wildlife Conservation Society DWNP and WWF Malaysia Taman Negara EndauRompin and Royal Belum among the seven areas studied More studies are needed beyond these areas
In order to obtain a reliable estimate for the whole country it is important that additional forested areas are also studied It remains difficult to estimate tiger population and compare data from previous years A definitive comparison with previous estimates quoted in the baseline figure is not advisable as the previous method of data collection and extrapolation is different

description.narrative: Systemic Institutional Capacities to manage and financially support a national PA System
Establishment of the policy framework for the National PA system

comment.narrative: No framework exists resulting in a fragmented PA system with a large number of PAs gazetted under different acts based on varied management standards
A single framework with clear categorisation of all the PAs in the PA Master List in Peninsular Malaysia with uniform accepted management standards and reporting requirements

The project has improvised the initial plan of using PoWPA Action Plan as a platform to develop the National Framework for PA due to the process of finalizing the PoWPA Action Plan led by the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment NRE is still ongoing and yet to reach consensus among the key federal and state agencies
The project has since taken a proactive approach by carried out consultations with key state governments including Sabah and Sarawak where some States have agreed in principle to develop a common National Framework standard definition and management practices for PAs A draft Terms of Reference TOR for national experts was initially developed in March 2015 Following consultation with DWNP and UNDP the decision was made to engage two national experts to focus on two key areas i Legal and Enabling Environment for Establishing a National Framework and ii Basis and outline for the National Framework The TORs have been prepared and they are now being finalized for advertisement in September 2015 It is expected that the National Framework to complete by end of 2016
The ongoing preparation of the Management and Business Plans for the three target PA sites also contributes to the development of National Framework for PA by drafting a common management and business plan template which could form the basis of a common template for nationwide adoption Key agencies will be invited to give their inputs to the prototype template to ensure its applicability in different PA contexts across the country

description.narrative: Financial incentive system based primarily on performance indices established and operational

comment.narrative: No performancelinked financial incentive system exists
System established supporting a minimum of 866000 ha of the PA estate

The establishment of the National Natural Resources Conservation Trust in 2014 provides an opportunity to pilot the performancebased financing system for protected areas As such the project has developed governance structure and drafted the operating guidelines for the National Natural Resources Conservation Trust Fund NCTF and submitted to the Ministry of Natural Resources and Environment NRE
The draft Operating Guidelines include general criteria for project selection appropriate indicators and ME system but it does not specify PA related performance indicators for PA related projectsinitiatives
The Operating Guidelines were tabled at the first meeting of the NCTF Board held on 21 April 2015 There has been limited feedback received from NRE regarding the performance indicators for PA related project selection under the NCTF

description.narrative: Integrated PA information and performance monitoring system

comment.narrative: Neither performance criteria nor monitoring systems specific to PA management exist
A national integrated PA information system established with the primary function of PA performance monitoring and decision support for relevant government bodies

Data on PAs is fragmented and dispersed the project has been identifying the best agency to host the database Initial consultation with the Forest Institute of Malaysia FRIM which is responsible for updating and maintaining the National Biodiversity Clearing House Mechanism established in 2008 indicates their support for hosting a PA database within the CHMs Biodiversity Database which can support decisionmaking in the planning and management of PA It is envisaged that the CHM can serve as an accessible and userfriendly platform for housing information on PAs in the country
As an interim measure the project is developing a PA profile template that captures essential managementoriented data and information of three target PA sites and PAs within the three PA Networks Having demonstrated the usefulness of this template for gathering and collating data on PAs the project will seek cooperation of relevant PA agencies to complete the actual database which will ultimately resides with FRIM

description.narrative:
National PA System mainstreamed in the budgeting process for 5year Malaysia Plan
Increased number of bankable projects in support of PA management approved for funding through operational grants

comment.narrative: No budget line for PA management in Malaysia Plan Currently the budgets for PA infrastructure development is determined based on individual requests from State governments with no systematic planning looking at conservation priorities of the national PA network as a whole

Dedicated PA budget line in Malaysia Plan
Budgeting process of PA managementdevelopment is conducted based on increased levels of conservation priorities within the Federal and State funding system using a range of tools including economic valuation results

The 11th Malaysia Plan 2016 2020 the 5year development plan was launched in May 2015 with six strategic thrusts where Strategic Thrust 4 Pursuing Green Growth for Sustainability and Resilience has identified conservation of protected areas as one of the focus areas Focus Area C Strategy C1 The Focus Area A also includes a strategy on sustainable financing mechanisms such as green tax carbon tax REDD etc Please refer to uploaded file on 11th Malaysia Plan and Strategy Paper 12
The NRE provided its inputs into the 11th Malaysia Plan through the submission of a draft strategy paper on biodiversity and environmental management of project proposals for consideration under the 11th Malaysia Plan Each of the three focal sites and their respective PA agencies have applied for budget allocations under the 11th Malaysia Plan
There is no dedicated budget line for PA in 11th Malaysia Plan The main criteria for all project selection including PA related projects is Creativity Index where proposed projects need to demonstrate low cost and high impacts to income cost of living simplicity and convenience health safety security harmony recreation and national pride and environmental sustainability

description.narrative: Technical and institutional capacities to manage subnational PA networks including capacities for effective financial management
Coordination between the subPA network agencies

comment.narrative: Minimal coordination mechanisms
Three agencies have common management approaches PA performance monitoring mechanisms and capacity development programmes

A stronger basis for standardizing approaches for PA management is being advanced through the projects initiatives to build support for a common National Framework for PAs In addition these aspects are also expected to be enhanced through the development of a standard template for the PA management and business plan
Through the transformation programme being implemented for the IBD by October 2015 there will be a common national training platform for personnel from PA agencies In addition the project continues to facilitate training and exposure opportunities such as participation in the Korea Friendship Park Programme 2 participants July 2015 and support for additional participants in the Advanced Training Course at the Wildlife Institute of India Nov 2015
To enhance coordination with PA agencies and state governments the project coordinators at the state level are playing an active role and enabling the project to respond to needs identified by PA agencies For 2015 an Interpretative Skills course has been developed for staff and local community at Endau Rompin National Park while a learning and exchange activity is being planned for staff government officers and community representatives from Taman Negara National Park

description.narrative: Economic and financial planning capacity institutionalized in the three subnational PA network agencies

comment.narrative: There is minimal human capacity or institutional structure to address issues of financial sustainability
A unit is established in each of the subnational PA agency dedicated to revenue diversification that will ensure financial sustainability

In consultation with the three PA agencies the project has ascertained that all agencies already have specific units in place that are responsible for financial planning In view of this it was recommended that the focus of the PA Financing project should be to enhance the skills for sustainable financial planning within these units Current practices are mainly based on government budgetary allocations and there is limited focus at present on diversification of funding sources and ensuring performancebased financing All Federal Ministries and agencies are expected to apply outcomebased budgeting in 20162017 onward
The business plan development is expected to provide guidance and best practices to PA networks on potential mechanisms and modality for revenue diversification and sustainable financing mechanisms

description.narrative: Financing gap decreased by at least 25 in the target PA subnetworks PSPC DWNP

comment.narrative:
Current financing gaps based on regional benchmark of 196 staff per 1000 km and US 1000 per km are
DWNP MYR869 million US290 million
PSPC MYR212 million US071 million
An average 25 decrease in the financing gaps of the 3 PA sub network agencies in real terms through operationalisation of financial management and revenue diversification models across the sites

The business plans currently being developed with the project support will help to project the financial and capacity gaps at Taman Negara EndauRompin and Royal Belum within Malaysian context Efforts also being planned to undertake financial planning analysis at PA Networks level together with TEEB analysis All the three PA Networks registered notable increase in year 2014 operating budget allocation compared to 2013
The financing gaps are
DWNP US548 million 22 reduction from 2012 level
PSPC US178 million 2 decrease from 2012 level
In terms of development budget in 2014 both networks PSPC and JNPC received additional allocation from the Federal Government for ecotourism related infrastructure development

description.narrative:
Increase in capacity development indicator score for three target subnational PA networks
DWNP
JNPC
PSPC

comment.narrative:
Average 54
61
61
45

An average gt10 increase of the capacity development indicator score for each target subnational PA networks
70
70
55

Capacity scorecards for the three target subnational PA networks was reviewed between March and May 2015 The scores obtained were as follows
DWNP 635
JNPC 635
PSPC 552
JNPCs improved scores is mainly due to the following areas
1 Strengthened legal capacity for enforcement arising from the revision of JNPC Enactment
2 A total of 39 permanent posts had been approved for JNPC in 2014 As a result 39 contract and daily paid staff will be upgraded to permanent positions in 2015 This is a significant development for ensuring job security and strengthening prospects for career development of protected area personnel
PSPC has exceeded the end of project target level Main improvements are stemmed from actions taken to strengthen the State Park Enactment to improve enforcement and penalties In addition cooperation between PSPC and other agencies DWNP State Forestry Department and the Royal Army Force through the 1MBEON has helped to strengthen the enforcement operations of PAs Efforts are being made to increase the number of staff positions in PSPC
An Integrated Management Plan has been prepared by NCIA in 2012 covering 10 years It covers some macrolevel planning aspects for PSPC and has placed emphasis on Perak establishing itself as a major destination for ecotourism with Royal Belum being the jewel in the crown of its PA network These developments are anticipated to lend support for the need to professionalise and strengthen effective management of the park There is a stronger basis now to set a higher target for the remainder of the project period

description.narrative: Number of PAs successfully meeting national management criteria and accessing performancebased financial transfers from the Federal system

comment.narrative: No baseline exists
At least eight 8 among the terrestrial PAs over 20000 ha under DWNP JNPC and PSPC

The national management criteria for performancebased financial transfers from federal to subnational is yet to be established It is expected to be pilot tested through the implementation of National Natural Resources Conservation Trust Fund by end of 2015 Application of performance monitoring and evaluation mechanism will be part of Trust Fund operationalization process In addition the development of management plans for the three target sites will provide important feedback to establishing the basis for national management criteria

title.narrative: PIMS 5191 National Access and Benefit Sharing Framework

description.narrative: Developing and Implementing a National Access and Benefit Sharing Framework in Malaysia

title.narrative: national access and benefit sharing framework in Malaysia (ABS II) Signed ProDoc
PIMS 5191 National Access and Benefit Sharing Framework

description.narrative: To enable the country with her rich biodiversity and biological resources to generate economic and social benefits for the country, benfitting stakeholders including indigenous and local communities.
independent political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

To strengthen the conservation and sustainable use of biological and genetic resources in Malaysia through developing the national framework for the implementation of Access and Benefit Sharing under CBD
Financial and funding mechanisms for the management of ABS monetary benefits

comment.narrative: No mechanism exists
Financial and funding mechanisms established and operational for the reinvestment of proceeds from ABS agreements into conservation

The terms of reference on the establishment of financial and funding mechanism for the management of ABS proceedsmonetary benefits has been prepared reviewed and endorsed by the National Steering Committee meeting that met in May 2015 Such mechanism is needed to ensure monetary benefits are managed in a systematic way thereby implementing the overall objective for conservation

description.narrative: National ABS law regulations and institutional framework in place which will enable Malaysia to accede to the Nagoya Protocol

comment.narrative: No national law regulations or operational institutional framework state legislation on ABS only exists for Sabah and Sarawak
National law and implementing regulations on ABS come into force by end of project and are applied by national and state Competent Authorities

All stakeholders consultations were completed federal agencies state agencies research institutions NGOs Communities and private sectors The draft Act is ready for submission in Parliament However at the moment the Attorney Generals Office is finalising the incorporations of some final comments made by research institutions NRE with the technical assistance of the Centre of Excellence of Biodiversity Law CEBLAW main focus in 2015 is to finalize the draft ABS bill and facilitate the process for the bill to be adopted by the Parliament in 2015 Finetuning of the draft ABS regulation will be conducted parallel to the process of finalizing the ABS draft Bill in the second half of 2015

description.narrative: An operational national regulatory and institutional framework on ABS

Financial and funding mechanisms established at federal and state levels to receive and reinvest proceeds from ABS agreements towards the conservation of biological diversity and sustainable use of its components

comment.narrative: No formal governmental financial mechanism exists for reinvesting proceeds from ABS agreements towards the conservation of biological diversity and sustainable use of its components

Financial and funding mechanisms established at federal and state levels by end of Year 3 to receive and reinvest proceeds from ABS agreements towards the conservation of biological diversity and sustainable use of its components

The TOR for the study on establishment of financial and funding mechanism to manage ABS proceeds monetary benefits has been developed reviews and endorsed in the National Steering Committee NSC meeting that met in May 2015 The study corresponds to the draft ABS law which include a provision that all monetary benefits where the Federal or state government is not the resource provider may require some percentage of monetary benefits to be deposited into fund that maybe established by the federal or state government to support conservation related activities

description.narrative: Institutional framework for sui generis systems for protection of traditional knowledge and customary uses of biological resources developed under the auspices of SaBC and used to inform national framework development

comment.narrative: No institutional framework for sui generis systems for protection of traditional knowledge and customary uses of biological resources exist for Malaysia

Supportive institutional framework for sui generis systems for protecting traditional knowledge innovations and practices and customary uses of biological resources developed forSabah State and used to inform national framework development

Sabah Biodiversity Council had given the approval for Sabah Biodiversity Centre SaBC to implement output 14 of the project on 26 February 2015 The Secretary of Natural Resources Office NRO has been appointed to chair the technical committee to monitor the implementation of the project
The actual work for output 14 by SaBC has not commenced The earlier proposed project by SaBC which is the development of a PIC communitty Protocol in Long Pasia Sabah needs to be revisited and a discussion on this matter is planned in the second half of 2015 This is to ensure that the project contribute to the overall ABS national as well as the states ABS processes

description.narrative: National and State Competent Authorities identified and operational for full implementation of national law and regulations on ABS

comment.narrative:
No national competent authority state competent authorities only exist for Sabah and Sarawak1
1 Sabah Biodiversity Centre and Sarawak Biodiversity Centre and Sarawak Forestry Corporation
National and State Competent Authorities identified for all 13 States and operational for full implementation of national law and regulations on ABS by end of project

Potential Competent Authorities CAs from all 13 states in Malaysia as well as some relevant federal ministries and agencies have been identified and are listed as Schedule 1 in the draft ABS law The CAs identified are the Ministry of Federal Territories state economic planning unit for the state of Kedah Kelantan Melaka Johor Pahang Penang Perak Perlis Selangor Terengganu Sabah Biodiversity Council and the Ministry Of Resource Planning And Environment Sarawak CAs will be responsible to oversee ABS matters in state especially in issuing access permit In the process of obtaining and finalising the list of Competent Authorities from states and other ministryagencies briefings conducted on 5 March 2014 and 29 January 2015 have increased the understanding of ABS issues among states the relevant ministries and agencies
in all states has been identified and currently some form of awareness is being done especially to ensure the nominated CA knows their roles in implementing the regulations later

description.narrative: National law and implementing regulations on ABS come into force

comment.narrative: No national law state legislation on ABS only exists for Sabah and Sarawak
National law and implementing regulations on ABS come into force by year 2

The draft ABS law has been finetuned based on inputs from the briefing held on 29 January 2015 A draft implementing regulation has been prepared and will be updated and consulted following the same process of open consultation as the draft ABS national law

description.narrative: Best practice ABS processes three are demonstrated recognizing the principles of biodiversity conservation Prior Informed Consent PIC and Mutually Agreed Terms MAT including the fair and equitable sharing of benefits
At least 80 of the population of ILCs participating in the pilot projects are aware of the existence use and option values of the biological resources under their stewardship

comment.narrative: The KAP study will established the baseline on the awareness level of the selected stakeholders under the KAP survey The result is expected to be presented in November 2015

description.narrative: Number of ABS pilot agreements negotiated for initial commercialization of prototypes with fair and equitable benefit sharing provisions

comment.narrative: No ABS agreements in Malaysia that fully comply with CBD requirements
At least 2 ABS pilot agreements negotiated for initial commercialization of prototypes with fair and equitable benefit sharing provisions

The Forest Research Institute Malaysia FRIM and Sarawak Biodiversity Centre SBC are involved in implementing the pilot activities under outcome 3 FRIMs activities has been focused on documenting traditional knowledge from the Kintaq and Kensiu subethnic in the state of Perak and Kedah As of May 2015 10 plant species that are picked based on their utilisation linked to traditional knowledge are now under lab examination for further screening to determine their biological compound with the objective of deriving a nutraceuticalhealthcare product to be commercialised
SBCs planned pilot agreement will be done on plant based product derived from the Litsea cubeba plant which produces fragrant oil that can be used in many personal care product SBC is working very closely with the Lun bawang and Bidayuh Commuinty at Kg Kiding SBC is communicating with University of Portland Oregon on conducting a feasibility study for Litsea based products to be marketed in the USA

description.narrative: Number of ABS agreements arising from the pilot projects that specify conservation measures to ensure the security of the concerned biological resources

comment.narrative: No ABS agreements in Malaysia that fully comply with CBD requirements or include specified conservation measures for related biological resources
At least 2 ABS pilot agreements negotiated that when necessary include in situ andor ex situ conservation measures to ensure the security of the concerned biological resources
No progress yet expected to be completed by the final year of the project

description.narrative: Number of best practice pilot ABS agreements and PIC processes disseminated at regional level

comment.narrative: Malaysia participates in UNEPGEF ASEAN ABS project but has limited experience to contribute to date
Best practice pilot ABS agreements and PIC processes presented at international workshop for ASEAN countries in Year 4 published in workshop proceedings and made available through NRE website
This output on sharing of best practices is envisaged to be implemented in the final year of the project where substantive project results and pilot agreements will be already in place

description.narrative:
Number of PIC processes1 with ILCs implemented in accordance with the planned PICcommunity protocol
1 These would be the processes leading up to the signing of ABS pilot agreements above

comment.narrative: Some developmental work in Sabah and Sarawak on PIC processes
At least 3 PIC processes with ILCs implemented in accordance with the planned PICcommunity protocol

Since a standard prior informed consent protocol is not in place FRIM is conducting their pilot project following their own PIC that observes the requirement of the Convention on Biological Diversity CBD FRIMs has obtained the first level of PIC from Kintaq and Kensiu subethnic of which were to obtain their consent to participate in the TK documentation programme to identify potential products to be developed

description.narrative: Strengthened national institutional and stakeholder capacity for implementation of the national ABS framework
Improved capacities of national and state competent authorities for ABS implementation as shown byan increase of at least 30 in thedraft ABS Capacity Development Scorecard

comment.narrative:
ABS Capacity Scorecard baselines
NRE 33
Sabah 35
Sarawak 31
Other states 0
Other agencies0

ABS Capacity Scorecard targets
NRE 75
Sabah 75
Sarawak 75
Other states 30
Other agencies 30

The next capacity scorecard assessment will be conducted before the midterm review of the project in 2016 Upon the adoption of the draft national ABS bill in Cabinet and passing by the Parliament NRE plans to conduct targeted capacity building to the identified CAs on how to deal with access application and monitoring compliance by user of biological resources The capacity building or training to CAs as the regulators will be done based on a module that includes incorporating guidelines on mutually agreed terms and benefit sharing The training for CAs is expected to be conducted by early 2016

description.narrative: Number of NCA state and related agencies trained on ABS and bioprospecting related subjects to facilitate implementation of the national ABS framework 1

comment.narrative: No staff have been trained
100 staff from the NCA 13 state CAs and related agencies see footnote are trained

No training has been conducted as the draft ABS law has not been passed and so does the list of CAs named in the draft law Training will be done based on a specific training module to CAsregulators which is now under development and trainings are expected to be started in early 2016

description.narrative: Percentage of the population of researchers local communities and relevant industry targeted by the campaign is aware of the national law and CBD and NP provisions related to ABS and traditional knowledge TK among stakeholders including researchers public ILCs and industries2

comment.narrative: The KAP study which is expected to commenced in July 2015 will produce the baseline on the awareness of stakeholders on the issue of ABS The baseline is expected to be produced in November 2015

title.narrative: Third National Communication and Biennial Reporting

description.narrative: Third National Communication and Biennial Update Reporting to the United Nations Framework Convention on Climate Change

title.narrative: Third National Communication and Biennial Reporting

description.narrative: Submission of the Third National Communication (TNC) and the updating of the GHG Inventory by the submission of the Biennial Update Reporting (BUR) as part of the obligations under the United Nations Framework Convention for Climate Change (UNFCCC).
independent political entity
Institutional Strengthening Phase 10
Institutional Strengthening Phase 10
independent political entity
Framework for the Implementation of Sustainable Development in Malaysia in Support of the Post-2015 Sustainable Development Goals (SDG)

The project aims to address three key implementation challenges of sustainable development in Malaysia, namely policy coherence, governance, human capacity to implement best practices/solutions, monitor and evaluate outcomes of relevant programmes.
independent political entity

1.1 National Sustainable Development Blueprint is developed. 1.2 Institutional framework for sustainable development is proposed and submitted to National Development Planning Committee. 2.1 Communication and advocacy strategy for sustainable development is developed. 2.2 20% increase in the level of public awareness on sustainable development based on survey. 3.1 Outline of SD registry.

comment.narrative: 1.1 No overarching national sustainable development strategy exists. 1.2 Fragmented institutional framework for sustainable development. 2.1 No communication and advocacy strategy for sustainable development. 2.2 Baseline level of public awareness on sustainable development based on survey. 3.1 No systematic mechanism and capacity to identify, analyse and consolidate best practices and solutions for sustainable development.
1.1 Gap analysis of policy, institutional and data response for SDGs completed in August 2015. 1.2 National implementation plan for sustainable development is proposed by November 2015.

1.1 Final report for the gap analysis for an implementation framework in preparation of the SDGs was completed in August and finalized in December 2015. 1.2 As requested by the Government, the formulation of the national implementation plan for sustainable development will begin once the SDG indicators are finalized in March 2016.
3.1 Proceedings for the SDG Symposium: Operationalising the 2030 Agenda for Sustainable Development completed by 30 June 2016.

title.narrative: Improving Connectivity in Central Forest Spine

description.narrative: Sustainable Forest landscape management in the Central Forest Spine to secure critical wildlife habitats, conserve biodiversity and carbon stokcs and maintain the continous flow of multiple ecosystems services.

title.narrative: Improving Connectivity in Central Forest Spine
Improving Connectivity in Central Forest Spine
Improving Connectivity in Central Forest Spine
Improving Connectivity in Central Forest Spine
Improving Connectivity in Central Forest Spine
Improving Connectivity in Central Forest Spine
Improving Connectivity in Central Forest Spine

description.narrative: This project will conserve biodiversity and ecosystem services in three critical landscapes of the Central Forest Spine, by supporting the country’s CFS Master Plan to restore connectivity between forest complexes.
independent political entity
Environment - policy, planning and administration

To increase federal and state level capacity to execute the CFSMP through the strengthening of institutional and operational structures and the piloting of sustainable forest landscape management plans in three tigerpriority landscapes financed sustainably through the diversification of funding sources for conservation
Funds invested into CFS conservation apart from GEF funds

comment.narrative: Currently mostly government or ad hoc NGO funding
CFS conservation fund receiving regular income through diverse sources
The government of Malaysia has set up a national Conservation Trust Fund with a seed fund of RM10 million The project will support the operationalization of the trust fund for CFS activities

description.narrative: Natural forest of 4 forest blocks of CFS Main Range Forest Complex Southeast Pahang Peat Swamp Forest Greater Taman Negara complex EndauRompinSedili complex

comment.narrative: 45 million ha of PRF and National Park in CFS complexes
No net loss of forested area with 95 remaining natural forest

Project is still in the inception phase from November 2014 to 30 June 2015 Activities of the project have not been carried out yet The BII Technical Working Group TWG have started consultations to carry out the activities that relate to their outputs including the involvement of taxonomists and stocktaking for both flora and fauna Some stakeholders have suggested changes to the targets and discussions are ongoing

description.narrative: Overall score of CFS Capacity Development Scorecard

comment.narrative: Current score is 12
Score of at least 22 by project end
The next assessment will be conducted prior to the mid term review

description.narrative: Biodiversity and ecosystem service provision is mainstreamed in forest landscape management in the three priority landscapes via sustainable forest landscape management plans resulting in maintained status of biodiversity and ecosystem services
GEF Land Degradation3 Tracking Tool score

comment.narrative: Currently a score of 5 out of a possible 10
A score of at least 9 by end of project
In progress Next assessment will be done prior to the midterm review

description.narrative: Multistakeholder landscape management plan implemented in each landscape informed by biodiversity ecosystem services and carbon stocks values

comment.narrative: Currently only BelumTemengor has an integrated landscape management plan formed without the use of environmental monitoring and management planning tools
693500 ha across the three focal landscapes is under improved management incorporating environmental monitoring and management tools

In progress The NSC was informed by the State governments that they will organise state level resources to facilitate identification management and monitoring of all PLs and SLs while project activities are being implemented

description.narrative: Status of biodiversity in the CFS

comment.narrative: The preliminary baseline BII lies between 48 and 68 this will be refined at the start of the project building on PPGstage analysis
BII of the CFS has not decreased below score at start of project
In progress Next assessment will be done prior to the midterm review Related outputs for 211 and 213 which are carried out by FRIM are ongoing

description.narrative: Corridor establishment increases connectivity of critical ecological linkages identified in the CFSMP and supports carbon emission avoidance and carbon sequestration under SFM practices
GEF SFMREDD tracking tool

comment.narrative: Baseline score is 6 out of a possible 11
Avoided emissions of 149 million tC due to 20000 ha gazetted 17600tCyr due to ARR activities in 4000 ha tracking tool score of at least 10
The Perak State government has gazetted around 19000 ha along the Belum Temenggor Forest Complex as part of its commitment of CFS initiative

description.narrative: Presence of wildlife in corridor areas

comment.narrative: Connectivity between forest patches is low and restricts wildlife movement particularly in unprotected areas
An additional 20000 ha gazetted 4000 ha rehabilitated and wildlife crossings established encourage increased presence and movement of wildlife in these areas
In progress Outputs related to 223 on wildlife crossing is ongoing and led by PERHILITAN

description.narrative: Enhanced wildlife crime law enforcement and wildlife monitoring capacity emplaced at national and state levels and in target forest landscapes to ensure reduction of wildlife and forestry crime
Percentage of recorded wildlife crime cases that are prosecuted and convicted in court

comment.narrative: Between 2011 and 2012 just 13 of cases recorded by DWNP were prosecuted in court
At least 70 of recorded wildlife crime cases are prosecuted in court and given the legally stated penalty
To be gauged prior to the midterm review

description.narrative: Tiger populations in source PAs

comment.narrative: Estimated to be 03 individuals per 10000 ha
Population increased by at least 20

The Wildlife Conservation TWG have completed discussions with stakeholders especially on tiger population targets indicators The TWG has decided to change the tiger population density from 03 individuals per 10000 ha to 08 individuals per 100km2 based on recent studies by MYCAT and PERHILITAN The tiger survey by respective organisations including WWFM PERHILITAN and WCS is ongoing

description.narrative: Funding allocations for biodiversity and ecosystem conservation in the CFS are secured and formalised
Coordinated mechanism in place for attracting earmarking and administering funding for biodiversity and ecosystem conservation in the CFS

comment.narrative: Fundraising and financial flows for conservation in the CFS largely uncoordinated between different agencies and organisations

With significantly reduced dependence on funds from federal budgets and NGOs the conservation of the CFS is directed and managed via the dedicated fund without influence of national economic circumstances
The TWG at the Forestry Department will keep track of this Recent government approval of RM50 million for wildlife Survey is very encouraging

description.narrative: Strategic planning processes in place and being used to link financing to conservation management needs
CFS conservation management is supported by sustainable financing plans

comment.narrative: Budget preparation and planning in government conservation agencies largely delinked from CFS conservation management plans
One CFSwide and 3 statelevel sustainable financing plans ensure that landscapes are managed sustainably dependent in the long term on the values of their biodiversity and ecosystem services
Expected to be carried out in 2018

description.narrative: Strengthened institutional capacity of the Federal Government to oversee implementation of the CFSMP ensuring compliance by subnational actors and monitoring impacts upon biodiversity ecosystems and carbon stocks
Existence of environmental monitoring and management systems applicable to landscape management planning

comment.narrative: There are no effective mechanisms in place for incorporating biodiversity ecosystem services and carbon stocks considerations into landscape management planning
Environmental monitoring and management tools developed under Outputs 111114 are positioned for application in landscape management planning across the peninsula

Project is still in the inception phase from November 2014 to 30 June 2015 Activities of the project have not been carried out yet The BII Technical Working Group TWG have started consultations to carry out the activities that relate to their outputs including the involvement of taxonomists and stocktaking for both flora and fauna Some stakeholders have suggested changes to the targets and discussions are ongoing

description.narrative: National CFS steering committee equipped to apply environmental monitoring and management tools in supervision of state level landscape management planning and monitoring of compliance to CFSMP

comment.narrative: National CFS steering committee has little knowledge on applications of environmental considerations in landscape management planning and monitoring

National CFS steering committee is fully trained in the application of the tools developed under Outputs 111114 for supervision of state level landscape management planning and monitoring of compliance to CFSMP
The outputs for these are not carried out yet This is expected to be done in year 3 after the tools are done between year 1 and year 3

description.narrative: The long term biodiversity and ecosystem conservation of the CFS is enhanced through the diversification of funding sources for conservation
New and additional sources of funding for conservation in the CFS are in place of at least 1 million by EoP and functioning as reflected in BD2 TT

comment.narrative: CFS conservation funding dependent on government budgets and NGOdonor projects
Funds are regularly contributed towards CFS conservation through four separate streams under Outputs 311314
In Progress Output 311 and 313 are ongoing The TWG in Forestry Department will work with Federal Economic Planning Unit and State Planning Units

description.narrative: The socioeconomic status of local communities improved and support for conservation increased through the generation of sustainable livelihoods based on wildlife and the reduction of humanwildlife conflict
Conservationrelated livelihood activities involving both men and women established in pilot areas and making significant contributions to household income of Orang Asli participants

comment.narrative: Baseline household income gained from different livelihood activities undertaken by both men and women to be established at start of project disaggregated by gender Some craft groups exist in BelumTemengor but have been given little support and opportunity to develop
At least two ecotourism and handicrafts CBOs in operation with proven engagement of both men and women and increasing household income of participants by 25

Outputs regarding 231 on ecotourism led by both FDPM and PERHILITAN is ongoing In relation to this the Johor TWG is in the process of being established with the involvement of DWNP and other relevant agencies An elephant sanctuary is in the process of being gazetted

description.narrative: Number of reported HWC incidences within communities and level of economic loss for men women and households in general

comment.narrative: In 2012 111 wildlife complaints were recorded in BelumTemengor 19 complaints were recorded in EndauRompin Baseline for economic losses to be established at start of project disaggregated by gender
Reports of HWC incidences reduced by 25 in target communities and economic losses reduced by 25

title.narrative: Green Technology Application Low Carbon Cities

description.narrative: The objective is to achieve sustainable development, reduce carbon emissions of the cities and contribute towards the national commitment of reducing up to 40% of GHGs in terms of emission intensity by GDP by the year 2020 compared to 2005 levels.
Facilitate the implementation of low carbon initiatives in at least five Malaysian cities and showcase a clear and integrated approach to low carbon development.
